item.title: How to Solve the Fuse Box Puzzle in Fear the Spotlight
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Fuse Box Puzzle Solution in Fear the Spotlight
    • How to Open the Fuse Box
    • Accessing the Storage and Bathrooms
    • Finding Fuse C and D
    • Accessing the Pool and the Office
    • Finding Fuse E and F
    • Powering the Gym

Fear the Spotlight transports players back to the PS1 era of horror survival games. It's filled with clever puzzles that challenge players and forces them to think outside the box. The second part of the game in Vivian's Story takes place in the Webber Building. However, after making your way past the first section of the game and arriving in front of the door to the facility, you'll find it filled with smoke.

To proceed, you'll need to clear out the smoke, which requires solving an elaborate puzzle involving a fuse box. While the puzzle can seem tricky at first, the pieces will start falling into place once you get started. For those struggling, here's a complete guide to solving the Fuse Box Puzzle in Fear the Spotlight.

Fuse Box Puzzle Solution in Fear the Spotlight

After making your way through the Rose Door, you'll arrive at the School Courtyard. The door to Webber Building will be right ahead, but interacting with the door tells you that you'll need to clear out the smoke inside the building before you can head in.

You'll find an HVAC unit on one side, but it's not powered. There's another door in the courtyard that leads to the Gymnasium. Go inside and head to the door marked Mechanical on the far left of the gym. You'll find a Power Diverter once you go inside, but you can't use it yet. Head down the stairs, and you'll arrive at the Fuse Box.

How to Open the Fuse Box

When you interact with the Fuse Box, you'll see that the door is locked. So, the first step to solving the puzzle is to unlock it. There are six symbols that you can click on, and a note on the left shows you the password: 3451.

There's a table on the left of the Fuse Box with the Fuse B item. Pick it up and interact with the note marked Coupled Attenuations on the Board. You'll see how the numbers relate to the different symbols marked on the Fuse Box. This is your main clue to unlocking the Fuse Box. Head back to the Fuse Box and click on the Symbols that match the numbers in the password to open it.

After unlocking it, you'll see a screen, a yellow multimeter dial, and two wires on the left section, along with six slots to insert the wires. On the right side, you'll find nine closed panels.

Accessing the Storage and Bathrooms

After opening the Fuse Boxes, move the Red and Black wires to the first set of slots. This will light up the panel on the top left and allow you to open it. Lift it, and you'll see that there's a Fuse missing. Place the Fuse B you picked up earlier in the empty slot to light up the next panel.

Move back to the left section of the Fuse Box and rotate the multimeter dial until the screen at the top lights up green. If you did everything correctly, the indicator at the top screen should be at 4, and the dial should be at x100 on the gray side.

Head back to the second panel on the right section and lift the cover. You'll see two dials and a slider at the bottom. Set the left dial to 4, as shown on the top screen on the left, and the right dial to 00. Set the slider to the left, and this will unlock the last panel in the row. Lift the cover and pull down the lever to open the shutters in the storage room and bathrooms.

Finding Fuse C and D

Now that you can access the Storage Room and the Bathrooms, return to the main Gymnasium hall. The shutter leading to the Bathrooms is malfunctioning, but you can get inside the Storage Room. Inside the Storage, you'll see a locked cabinet on your left. You'll need the Cabinet Keys to open it.

Move forward and crouch under the table to pick up the Flashlight. There's a vent just ahead that you can unscrew using the Screwdriver in your inventory. Go through the opening to get into the Girl's Bathroom.

You'll see someone inside the Bathroom Stall on the right, but you can't get into it just yet. As you walk towards the exit, the Bathroom Stall will open. Go back to it and pick up the Cabinet Keys. Head out of the Bathroom using the main door. You'll now arrive at the other side of the malfunctioning shutters. Go into the Boy's Bathroom next.

Use the lever on the right side to lift the shutters and unlock the shortcut back to the main hall.

Head towards the urinal and interact with the middle one. Vivian will say she sees something at the bottom but won't reach for it until you flush the black sludge. Interact with the flush and pick up the Fuse C. Now go back to the locked cabinet that you saw in the Storage Room earlier, use the Cabinet Keys to open it, and pick up Fuse D.

Accessing the Pool and the Office

After picking up the new set of fuses, you'll need to make your way back to the Fuse Box. But lo and behold, the Spotlight Head is back and is walking around the Gymnasium's main hall looking for you. Use the covers in the hall to get back to Mechanical.

Set the Red and Black wires to the second set of slots in the Fuse Box and lift up the first Panel in the second row. Place Fuse C and D in the two slots and open the next panel. On the left screen, set the dial to x10 facing downward and note that the indicator on the top screen reads 8.

On the second panel in the second row, set the left dial to 8 and the right dial to 0. Move the slider to the right, and the third panel will unlock. Lift it up and use the lever to open the shutters in the Pool and Office areas.

Finding Fuse E and F

Head back out of Mechanical and carefully avoid the Spotlight Head to get inside the Pool area. Move through the rubble and arrive at the pool to see that it's filled with the same black sludge you saw back at the urinal. You'll have to find a way to drain it. Head towards the ladder that leads into the pool and open it so that you can access it later.

Go inside the Pool Office and answer the phone. After the phone conversation, interact with the yellow sticky note on the computer screen to read it. It's a clue to the password you'll need shortly. There's another locked Storage Cabinet in the room. Open it using the Cabinet Keys in your inventory to grab the Fuse E. Note the locked safe on the corner of the office below the window.

Now interact with the Trophy Shelf and check the different trophies. You'll notice that both the girls' and boys' teams won gold in 1987. This is the password for the safe in the office. Go back to the safe and input the code to open it. Pick up the Pool Pump handle.

Walk out of the office and head left towards the stairs. Before you go up the stairs, use the lever to lift the grate and unlock the shortcut back to the main hall. Now, take the stairs up to the stands and head to the Pool Drain Pump control panel. Use the Pool Pump Handle on the slot and turn it all the way right. Click on the switches as they start blinking to drain the pool.

Now, head back to the pool ladder you found earlier and use it to go down. At the bottom, you'll see a table where you'll find another note from your Secret Admirer. There's also a drain pipe here where you'll find the Raffle Crank. Head back out using the ladder. Avoid the Spotlight Head that's now in the swimming pool area and make your way back to the main hall.

In the main hall of the Gymnasium, interact with the Tumbler on the stage and use the Raffle Crank. Rotate it counter-clockwise, and the Fuse F will roll out.

Give the Tumbler a few more spins to unlock an extra achievement in Fear the Spotlight .

Powering the Gym

Now that you have both Fuse E and F in your inventory, head back to the Fuse Box. Switch the wires to the bottom slot and place the fuses inside the first panel. Set the dial to X1 on the red side.

On the second panel, set the left dial to 1 and the right dial to dot and move the slider right. Open the last panel and use the lever.

With that, you've solved the Fuse Box puzzle and can now use the Power Diverter in Mechanical to transfer power to the HVAC unit outside the Webber Building. As you exit the gym, you'll see many elusive specters in the main hall. Don't worry; they won't attack you. Just walk out the door and head to the HVAC unit to arrive in front of the Theater in Fear the Spotlight.

item.title: Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom Complete Guide & Walkthrough
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Getting Started Tips & Tricks
    • Early-Game Guides, Tips, & Tricks
    • General Guides
  • Dungeon & Quest Walkthroughs
    • All Dungeon Guides
    • All Rift Guides
    • All Main Quest Guides
    • All Side Quest Guides
    • Minigame Guides
  • All Collectibles
    • Heart Piece Guides
    • Echo & Automaton Guides
    • Misc. Collectibles

The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom is the newest addition to the Zelda franchise, and the first to feature Zelda herself in the role of playable protagonist. Created by Nintendo and Grezzo , Echoes of Wisdom features the "classic" Zelda format, and is visually similar to Grezzo's previous entry into the franchise, the Link's Awakening remake . With Zelda front and center, Echoes of Wisdom makes several interesting changes to the formula, most notably to combat. However, at its core, this still remains a classic Zelda experience, one that bridges the gap between the "modern" and "classic" eras remarkably well.

The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom features a massive map for players to explore, with all the classic regions fans of the series have come to expect (plus a few surprises). As Zelda makes her way through Hyrule, she is accompanied by Tri, her trusted partner. Tri's abilities serve as the foundation for nearly every major mechanic in Echoes of Wisdom , including combat, exploration, and all collectibles . Zelda will use a huge system of Echoes (copies of items and enemies found in the world) to conquer her foes, traverse the world, and solve puzzles. Of course, Echoes of Wisdom also features several main dungeons to explore, items to collect, Heart Pieces to find, and secrets to reveal. All of it can be found through the many guides and walkthroughs featured in this hub, which serves as a complete guide and walkthrough for The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom.

  • Getting Started Tips & Tricks

    The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom features a huge amount of content, and certain aspects may be slightly overwhelming for new players. In this section, we will collect the guides that will help players get off to the best possible start. Whether its deciding which area to visit first , learning which Echoes are best for early-game combat and exploration, or covering important gameplay mechanics, our complete The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom walkthrough will will have you covered.

    • Early-Game Guides, Tips, & Tricks

      • Should You Go to Gerudo Desert or Jabul Waters First?
      • Eldin, Faron, or Lanayru: Where to Go First?
      • How to Upgrade Swordfighter Form (How to Get a Sword)
      • How to Summon More Echoes (Increase Tri Power)
      • How to Get a Horse (Early-Game)
      • How to Get Rupees Fast
      • How to Make Smoothies
      • How to Remove Zelda's Hood
      • How to Fly (Borrow Some Wings)
      • How to Dig
      • How to Break Spider Webs in Faron Wetlands

    • General Guides

      • How Long to Beat and How Many Dungeons
      • How to Use Amiibo
      • All Amiibo Rewards
      • How to Save Your Game
      • How to Unlock Fast Travel
      • Great Fairy Location
      • How to Use the Bow
      • How to Get & Use Bombs
      • All Wsaypoints in Echoes of Wisdom

  • Dungeon & Quest Walkthroughs

    It's no secret that classic dungeons are some of the most beloved aspects of the Zelda franchise, and The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom does not let fans down in this regard. This section will provide Echoes of Wisdom walkthroughs for each of main dungeons . This will include both the legacy dungeons, and the special Stilled rifts that act as smaller dungeon areas. Along with the dungeons, the game features a large number of main quests , side quests , and sub-quests that form the main narrative. This section of our complete Echoes of Wisdom walkthrough will feature all quest and dungeon content .

    • All Dungeon Guides

      • Suthorn Ruins Dungeon Walkthrough
      • Jabul Ruins Dungeon Walkthrough
      • Gerudo Sanctum Dungeon Walkthrough
      • Hyrule Castle Walkthrough
      • Eldin Temple Walkthrough
      • Faron Temple Walkthrough
      • Lanayru Temple Walkthrough
      • Null's Body Walkthrough
      • Cryptic Cavern Walkthrough

    • All Rift Guides

      • Stilled Upper Zora River (Tri's Friends)
      • Stilled Desert Temple Ruins (Tri's Friends)
      • Stilled Suthorn Forest Guide
      • Stilled Lake Hylia
      • Stilled Heart Lake Walkthrough
      • Stilled Faron Wetlands Walkthrough

    • All Main Quest Guides

      • Prison Stealth Section (Escape Hyrule Castle)
      • The Mysterious Rifts Walkthrough
      • Searching for Everyone Walkthrough
      • The Jabul Waters Rift Walkthrough
      • A Rift in the Gerudo Desert Walkthrough
      • A Rift in the Faron Wetlands Walkthrough
      • How to Get the Membership Card
      • Deku Scrub Lockup Walkthrough
      • Lands of the Goddesses Walkthrough
      • Eternal Forest Route & Pedestal Locations
      • Rescuing the Hero Link Walkthrough
      • [Spoiler] Boss Guide

    • All Side Quest Guides

      • All Side Quests
      • Up a Wall Quest Guide
      • A Curious Child Quest Guide
      • Questioning the Local Cats Quest Guide
      • A Treat for My Person Quest Guide
      • Recipes, Please! Quest Guide
      • The Flying Tile Quest Guide
      • Elusive Tumbleweeds Quest Guide
      • Tornado Ghost Quest Guide
      • Cuccos on the Loose Quest Guide
      • Impa's Gift Quest Guide (How to Get Zelda's Horse)
      • The Zora Child's Fate Quest Guide
      • Precious Treasure Guide
      • Performance Artist Quest Guide
      • The Flames of Fortune Quest Guide
      • One Soldier Too Many Quest Guide
      • Wild Sandstorms Quest Guide
      • Finding the Flying Plant Quest Guide
      • The Happy Shipwreck Quest Guide
      • Cotton Candy Hunt Quest Guide
      • Let's Play a Game Quest Guide

      • Get Rich Quick Quest Guide

      • Secret Chief Talks Quest Guide
      • Endless Stomach Quest Guide
      • Stamp Stand Swallowed Quest Guide
      • Ready Set Goron Quest Guide & Rewards
      • Glide Path & Glide Path Trailblazer Quest Guide & Rewards

      • Stamp Stand Swallowed! Quest Guide

    • Minigame Guides

      • Mango Rush Guide
      • Acorn Gathering Routes & Rewards
      • Slumber Dojo: All Challenge Guides & Rewards
      • Flag Race Minigame Guide

  • All Collectibles

    The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom features a huge number of collectibles for players to discover and collect. Spread around Hyrule, Zelda will find Heart Pieces , Might Crystals , Stamp Rally tables, and much more. Whether the effects are temporary, like the items needed for making Smoothies , or permanent, every collectible in Echoes of Wisdom is worth locating. This section of the complete Echoes of Wisdom guide and walkthrough will help players find all the game's collectibles.

    • Heart Piece Guides

      • All 40 Heart Pieces in Echoes of Wisdom

    • Echo & Automaton Guides

item.title: Final Fantasy: Best Elves In The Series, Ranked
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Original interpretations of elves in Final Fantasy include Elvaan and Elezen, showcasing diverse characterizations.
  • Characters like Queen Arbor and Lunera challenge traditional elven stereotypes, offering depth and development.
  • Archbishop Thordan IV subverts typical elven traits by being a power-hungry antagonist, defying player expectations.

While the fantasy genre is teeming with originality, elves have become a mystical staple of it - from the works of J. R. R. Tolkien to the Elder Scrolls franchise. As off-the-wall as Square Enix's Final Fantasy series can get at times, the genre-defining JRPG is no different.

Including more traditional portrayals of regular and Dark Elves, the Final Fantasy franchise has also incorporated multiple original interpretations of the character trope, with the likes of the Elvaan and Elezen people.

8 Queen Arbor

The Child-Like Queen Of The Forest-Dwelling Arbor People

Slightly brattish and mischievous at first glance, Queen Arbor of the city of the same name has an innate dislike of humans and halts players' progress in Final Fantasy: The Four Heroes of Light . Her short temper and tendency to lash out by transfiguring people into animals may cause players to dislike her. However, she does eventually aid the party after peace has been somewhat restored.

The matriarch of a woodland race of elves, the silver-haired Queen of Arbor develops over the course of the player's interactions with her. This ranges from being wholly disinterested in their plight, to not only reverting her magic but aiding them with the power to use 'Lux' - the ultimate White Magic spell in the game. Beyond that, in proving one's tenacity, players see that Queen Arbor's distrust has softened, and Elven-Human relations are once again opened.

7 Lunera

A Powerful Yet Kind Elf Of Lore & Legend

Existing as a historical character within Final Fantasy Brave Exvius , Lunera is not only portrayed as kind and skilled as a warrior but also welcoming of other non-elf races. Primarily developed through her portrayal in the narrative event 'A Promise Through Time,' Lunera's leadership and openness inspire her people, even if it still results in her untimely death.

Her acts cemented her as a figure in her culture's mythos for more than 700 years, as she is depicted believing that Elven people hold the responsibility of acting as moral aides to humanity rather than scorning them compared to much of the rest of her race. Ultimately perishing due to disease, Lunera's kindness and understanding sets her apart from many of her Elven contemporaries within Final Fantasy Brave Exvius and across the franchise, too.

6 Gramps / Freyr The Elf King

A Rude Intruder Turned Kind-Hearted Elven Monarch

  • First Appearance: Final Fantasy Dimensions
  • Released: September 06, 2010
  • Developer: Matrix Software
  • Platforms: FOMA 903i, iOS, Android
  • Genre: RPG

When players are first approached by Gramps in the dead of night around a campfire, many would likely be on their guard, especially when confronted by his blindness, amnesia, and lewd behavior. However, it comes to be that this rude old man is none other than the much-loved and respected King Fryer of the Elves.

While his rudeness is jarring, the eventual reveal of his real identity reveals the contrast between his alter ego and royal heritage. A highly skilled archer and selfless leader, his bait-and-switch reveal is still seemingly a highlight of Final Fantasy Dimensions ' narrative.

5 Prince Of Elfheim

The Original Introduction Of Elves In The Final Fantasy Franchise

Arguably one of the most notable example of an Elven character in the Final Fantasy franchise, the Prince of Elfheim plays an integral role in the narrative of the series' inaugural title.

Cursed to a seemingly eternal slumber by the dark elf Astos, players are tasked with waking him with the help of a Jolt Tonic. Adored by his people, who aided him as much as possible in the five years he was under, he provides the Warriors of Light with the Mystic Key that not only aids them in the plot of their adventure but can open optional rooms and doors throughout the game.

4 Fourchenault Leveilleur

A Powerful Sharlayan Who Upholds Tradition Despite Necessary Intervention

As an intelligent and powerful Mage at the heart of the Sharlayan Forum, Fourchenault is an integral conduit through which players of Final Fantasy 14 can learn more about the nation in the Northern Empty. A wildwood Elezen, he preaches the ideals of wisdom and reason while maintaining an infuriatingly stoic position on pacifism.

Although he proclaims that he seeks to uphold the traditions and culture of his people, he interacts with the player and other characters with a soft-spoken and gentle demeanor. However, players do see this personality shift as he is questioned by his children and Sharlayan's non-intervention is called into question. Despite upholding typical elvish values, Fourchenault does develop during Final Fantasy 14 's Shadowbringers and Endwalker expansions, culminating in him joining the player's party and providing some incredibly powerful magic during their battle during the 'Forlorn Glory' Role Quest.

3 Haurchefant Greystone

The Fan-Favorite Elezen Lord Who Meets A Warrior's End

  • Final Fantasy 14

Despite his noble upbringing as a Lord of House Fotemps, Haurchefant Greystone's openness and care for strangers runs firmly against not only his upper-class upbringing but also the superiority usually seen in elvish characters in fiction. Beyond this, his sincere yet romantic optimism has made him a fan-favorite companion in Final Fantasy 14 , which makes his heroic death all the more devastating.

His well-meaning character is bolstered in his time during the narrative of Final Fantasy 14 's A Realm Reborn expansion before his defense of the player from Ser Zephirin's spear of light in Final Fantasy 14: Heavensward proves deadly. Although he dies in the player's arms, his spirit does take the form of his sword and shield in defense of the Scions of the Seventh Dawn during Final Fantasy 14 's fourth expansion, Endwalker.

2 Prishe

The Smart-Mouthed Elvaan Who Rapidly Matures

Being impulsive, tomboyish, and foul-mouthed, Prishe is depicted as being incredibly different compared to other Elvaan people in Final Fantasy 11 .

Taking on a pivotal narrative role in the game's Chains of Promathia expansion, Prishe goes through arguably one of the most tumultuous periods of character development of any elf-like character in the franchise. Baptized by the Eye of Altana, she is detested by others of her race. However, she is ultimately cherished by her people later as she aids in their escape during the tumultuous fall of Tavnazia. Beyond this, she also grapples with ideas of self and meaning, as her immortality is stripped when Cardinal Mildaurion's control over her thoughts is removed.

1 Archbishop Thordan IV

A Power-Hungry Twisting Of Elven Character Tropes

  • Final Fantasy 14

While the depiction of elf-like characters in Final Fantasy varies greatly from person to person, they are often portrayed as being kindly and moral beings. As such, when Archbishop Thordan IV is presented as the firm but fair elderly leader of Ishgard, many players may have taken his appearance at face value.

However, beyond the elderly Elezen's wise and caring facade is the face of the primary antagonist of Final Fantasy 14 's Heavensward expansion. Venerated with dictatorial power, Thordan is power-hungry and deceitful, even placing his own son in the firing line as he pursues his goal of becoming a god-king. Condemning innocents is relatively par the course for power-hungry villains, yet as an elf-like character, Thordan throws off the expectations of players and makes for arguably one of the franchise's best surprise villains.

item.title: Hades 2: How to Get Star Dust (Chaos Trials)
item.description:
Updated October 25, 2024, by Christopher Norman Worcester: The Olympic Update for Hades 2 brought with it a wide range of new content, including a re-working of the Chaos Trial mechanic. This update will cover all the new additions to Chaos Trials i n Hades 2 , including Abyssal Reflection , the new Incantation that allows players to re-try previously completed trials.

Players making their way through Hades 2 will undoubtedly notice the massive amount of content already available in Early Access. The original was already overflowing with content, and now the sequel adds even more to the table before the game has even been fully released. While there is a lot of new content to unpack, one of the best additions is the Chaos Trials, which add a totally new gameplay system that rewards players with the rare Star Dust crafting material.

Hades 2 's Chaos Trials are a curated group of encounters that put Melino's battle prowess to the test. Given a pre-determined loadout, she must make her way through each trial to receive one of the game's rarest rewards. This guide will explain how to unlock Chaos Trials, and how to get the Star Dust it offers as a reward.

Hades 2 is currently in Early Access . This means that some elements of the game may change before its official 1.0 release. This guide will be updated regularly to reflect any changes to the subject it covers.

Chaos Trials and the Hades 2 Olympic Update, Explained

The Olympic Update for Hades 2 made some significant changes to the Chaos Trials system. Players can now re-try previously completed trials, though they will no longer be awarded Star Dust (S-Dust). Instead, each repeated attempt will earn you 50 Bones .

Abyssal Reflection Requirements:

Melinoe will not immediately have access to this new feature at the Pitch-Black Stone . She will have to complete one of the Olympic Update's new Incantations. The new Incantation requires the following materials:

Abyssal Reflection

Gain the ability to re-attempt cleared Trials at the Pitch-Black Stone for modest rewards of Bones

Moly x6 F-Fabric x2 Plasma x1

How to Unlock Chaos Trials in Hades 2

The basic steps to unlocking Chaos Trials in Hades 2 are relatively straightforward. The major requirement that players must meet is the completion of the Abyssal Night incantation. This unlocks the Pitch-Black Stone location in the Training Grounds, and allows access to the trials. How to unlock the Incantation itself, is a bit trickier to explain.

Currently, the exact requirements for receiving the incantation from Chaos are slightly nebulous. One thing is certain, however, and that is the fact that you must interact with Chaos multiple times before receiving Abyssal Night. In the playthrough that this guide is based on, the following conditions were met before receiving the incantation:

  • All five Nocturnal Arms were unlocked, and their Aspects were revealed (but not all unlocked).
  • The Warding Gate to the surface was removed, and the Unraveling a Fateful Bond incantation allowed Melino to survive above ground.
  • Chaos was visited several times via Chaos Gates, one Nectar was offered, and the Transcendent Embryo Keepsake was gained.
  • The Fated List of Minor Prophecies is unlocked, and several prophecies have been completed.

Abyssal Night was then offered to Melino during a normal encounter with Chaos, and was subsequently available at the Cauldron.

Abyssal Night Incantation Requirements:

Abyssal Night

  • Fate Fabric x2
  • Pearl x2
  • Moly x2
  • Nightshade x2

  • Fate Fabric is found through several different methods. The Wretched Broker sells them for 60 Bones each. Charon offers a shipment of 3 Obol Points. And Arachne usually offers a dress that gives grants one instantly.
  • Nightshade must be planted with seeds dug up in Erebus. Use the Silver Spade tool. They can then be planted after completing the Flourishing Soil incantation.

Once complete, the Pitch-Black Stone (which is actually pink in color) will be activated. It is found behind the Silver Pool in the Training Grounds.

How to Get Star Dust in Hades 2

Star Dust is primarily used for high-level Arcana upgrades, and brewing the Beast-Loved Morsel in the Cauldron , which allows for bonding with Animal Familiars.

Star Dust is the main reward for completing the various Chaos Trials offered at the Pitch-Black Stone. Interacting with the stone will reveal an informational window that explains how it works, followed by the main interface for starting the Chaos Trials.

Chaos Trials Explained:

The Chaos Trials allow Melino to face a series of combat trials that vary in difficulty. Each trial has its own predetermined elements, such as loadout and region. The first trail is called the Trial of Origin, which sends Melino into Erebus with the Witch's Staff. Many of the trials completely remove all Arcana, posing a significant challenge. The first set of available trials rewards the player with one Star Dust upon completion.

The Chaos Trial interface reveals information about each trial. In the above image, you can see that the Trial of Humility utilizes the Witch's Staff in Erebus. The series of pink dots on the right represent the trial's difficulty level, with five dots signaling a trial offering the highest challenge level. You can bet that the higher the challenge level, the less Melino will have when the trial begins.

Players may notice the Natural Talent minor prophecy on the Fated List. Since many of the Chaos Trails strip Melino of Arcana, completing a trial in Erebus will meet the requirements of this prophecy. It is therefore wise to wait until unlocking the Pitch-Black Stone to go about taking on this challenge.

Eventually, players will gain access to Star Dust from the Wretched Broker, who sells them for 800 Bones each. It is likely that players must complete at least one Chaos Trial before this is available, and they are assuredly not available before unlocking the Pitch-Black Stone.

Other Methods of Acquiring S-Dust:

As Hades 2 continues to be updated, new methods of getting Space Dust have become available. Players can now get S-Dust in Hades 2 through two characters: the Wretched Broker and Narcissus.

The Wretched Broker now sells S-Dust for 600 Bones. To get S-Dust from Narcissus, you'll have to enter the NPC chamber in Oceanus where he resides, and receive the Heavenly Splendor boon. We did not receive this boon until after we helped Narcissus and Echo come to terms with each other, and then cleared the murky water in Narcissus' chambers. It is not clear if this is a prerequisite, so keep a look out when you visit his chamber.

item.title: Final Fantasy: Best Viera Characters In The Series, Ranked
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Viera in Final Fantasy have diverse personalities and roles, such as assassins and adventurers.
  • Every Viera character, from Veis to Fran, brings unique traits to their respective games.
  • Mydia's transformation in Final Fantasy 12: Revenant Wings showcases the darker side of Viera lore.

Along the road to completing any Final Fantasy title, players will fill their hours with characters of many differing races and creeds. From fantasy hallmarks like humans and elves to wholly original and unique races such as the humanoid rabbit-like Viera.

Although they share a passion and responsibility towards nature, Viera can vary in personality and disposition. As a result, across the series' history, players have seen them take on a multitude of roles, from cat-burglers, assassins and archers.

8 Veis

The Vanishing Viera Assassin Who Assists The Player & House Bowen

Throughout players' adventures around Ivalice in Final Fantasy Tactics A2: Grimoire of the Rift , a suite of varied characters with even more varied roles can join the ranks of their group, Clan Gully, from Mages and Paladins to race-specific jobs such as Viera Assassins.

Integral to players learning the aforementioned Assassin job role, Veis the Viera engages with Clan Gully before promptly vanishing to join House Bowen if the correct quest markers have been hit. Her brooding demeanor is reinforced during gameplay, as her 'Vanish' ability allows her to disappear from enemy sights before promptly attacking from another unknown location. Appearing in typical Viera Assassin clothing, Veis' dialogue showcases the hubris and stoicism as a staple of the race.

7 Syrenead Sie Hyskarias

An Adventurous Girl Who Wants To Prove Her Worth To Her Community

  • Final Fantasy Tactics A2: Grimoire Of The Rift

Syrenead's seemingly underwhelming appearance may have caused some players of Final Fantasy Tactics A2: Grimoire of the Rift to write her off as a minor character with little to contribute to the game's narrative. However, her spunky nature and drive for acceptance create an endearing personality in a relatively throwaway Viera character in the Nintendo DS exclusive tactical RPG.

With the appearance of a typical green mage, Syrenead's appearance as a guest character brings with it her thrill-seeking tendencies. In trying to defeat a powerful Wyrm to prove to her father that she is capable, she enlists the player to assist her. Her 3-part quest culminating in the Wyrm being kept as a pet may seem obscure. Still, her drive to pursue dangerous situations transforms what could have been a forgettable Viera cameo into a grounded yet silly narrative about proving one's strength.

6 Relj

The Only Viera On The Kiltia Site Of Mount Bur-Omisace

When breaking Viera laws and setting out from her native homestead to pilgrimage around Final Fantasy 12 's realm of Ivalice, Relj was curious about the varied cultures and races around her. Unfortunately, with the selfishness and destruction of Hume warfare on full display, her Viera innocence and optimism are tarnished by the time players reach her.

As refugees of the Hume conflict flood to Relj's place of residence at the Kiltia religious center of Mount Bur-Omisace's peak, the seeming navet of the Viera people seen in Relj has been made weary. Although, through the work of players besting the Rank VIII Fanfir that has terrorized the land and recovering her companion Leeha's ring, she seems to not only regain some of her once-lost warmth but a newfound respect for the Hume race.

5 Shara

A Tight-Lipped & Lethal Archer With A Soft Spot For Ritz Malheur

Playing an incredibly active role in the assistance and adoration of Final Fantasy Tactics Advance 's female protagonist Ritz, Shara's seemingly unfazed demeanor acts as a fitting counterbalance to Ritz's short fuse.

As an active part of Ritz Malheur's clan, Shara's traits are consistent with the rural setting of the Viera people. Clothed in a relatively typical woodland garb and being an incredibly proficient archer, her appearance is fairly typical with other traditional Viera. Striking up a strong kinship with Ritz throughout the game's narrative while making her fear of insects transparent to the player, Shara's hard exterior is slowly peeled back to reveal the caring and fallible being beneath.

4 Jote

Fran & Mjrn's Eldest Sister And The Viera Elder Of Eruyt Village

  • Final Fantasy 12

While many of the Viera that players interact with in the Final Fantasy franchise are those who have disregarded the way of their native people, Jote stands firm as a stoic reminder of the rabbit-like race's culture and customs. Although she is the eldest of two other notable Viera characters in Final Fantasy 12 - being Fran and Mjrn - her position as the Elder of Eruyt Village determines that she is just as memorable.

Although her position as the village Elder necessitates that she remains calm and collected when faced with challenges, this can have the effect of portraying her as cold and distant. However, the love she has for her two sisters - who have left the village in stark contrast to Viera law - saddens her as she has to uphold the traditions and boundaries of her culture.

3 Krjn

A Founding Member Of Clan Centurio & A Proficient Fighter

  • Final Fantasy 12

Donned in dark armor and a foreboding mask design, Krjn's stoicism as one of the founders of Clan Centurio is on full display when players first meet her in Final Fantasy 12 . Being highly protective of her clan, sister, and community, she assists players in aiding her people.

Specifically when players are sent hunting a Rank VII Malboro named Carrot, her navigation and battle prowess are integral to discovering and besting the oversized beast. Playing a relatively minor speaking role, her position as a Clan hallmark leads her to travel where she is needed, which is most likely why she sees it necessary to aid in slaying Madame Zammadria's 'scandalous' mistake.

2 Mydia / Judge Of Wings

The Rebellious Viera Whose Anger Literally Transforms Her

Despite her initial Viera appearance, Mydia's grief and frustration transform her into not only a shadow of herself but an existential threat in the form of the Judge of Wings.

After falling in love and tumbling through grief, Mydia is possessed by Feolthanos the Eternal, and that rage is concentrated at her own people. The Feol subspecias of Viera, who are found in Final Fantasy 12: Revenant Wings , live in hiding - which is what spurred Mydia to adventure beyond the bounds of her homeland. Yet, before she dies, Feolthanos channels her emotions to commit effectively genocidal acts on her own Viera people. Although Feolthanos is ultmately defeated in his Exultant form, the damage resulting from his control of Mydia has already been done, and the Feol Viera people are seemingly wiped from existence as a result.

1 Fran

The Floppy-Eared Cat-Burgler Working Alongside Balthier

  • Final Fantasy 12

Arguably the most memorable Viera of the entire franchise, Fran has become a fan-favorite character as a result of her spunky nature and hidden soft side. First appearing in Final Fantasy 12 alongside fellow thief in the night Balthier, Fran's driving prowess and devil-may-care attitude have ensured that she has appeared in multiple spin-offs since her debut.

Joining the player's party in Final Fantasy 12 as one of the series' only playable Viera, the 'Master of Weapons' may show a discipline distinguishing her from others, yet her humanity shows through as her cut ties with her Viera kinfolk are slowly presented while pursuing the title's narrative.
